Summary I am a mathematician / statistician / computational biologist / programmer hybrid whose love of challenging, complex puzzles in the form of messy data sets and real-world problems has led her down the rabbit hole of immunology and genetics. My objectives are to develop and apply computational tools to meet the needs of the budding field of computational immunology, and to accelerate the discovery of genetic substrates of immune disease in the process. Summary I'm a statistician with a primary focus in biostatistics, epidemiology, and study design. I have worked on a broad range of academic biomedical projects and have independently conceived, designed, conducted, analyzed, and published behavioral psychology and epidemiology studies for more than 6 years.  
 
I hold an M.S. in Statistics and a B.A. in Psychology from Stanford University. Summary I'm a statistician with a primary focus in biostatistics, epidemiology, and study design. I hold an M.S. in Statistics and a B.A. in Psychology from Stanford University. Experience Biostatistician Stanford University School of Medicine, Quantitative Sciences Unit June 2014  – Present (1 year 3 months) I provide statistical support on all phases of research to principal investigators in the Stanford University School of Medicine. Areas of research have included oncology, nutrition, preventative health, infectious diseases, and cardiovascular disease. In these collaborations, I provide advice on study design, statistical analysis, and interpretation of results and perform statistical analysis for a variety of observational and experimental studies. I have served as a mentor for the Stanford Intensive Course in Clinical Research. Additionally, I collaborate on original research in applied statistics, currently focused on evaluating and extending imputation methods for longitudinal data with missing data in both time-varying and fixed correlated covariates. Biostatistician Stanford University School of Medicine, Department of Pulmonary and Critical Care June 2013  –  June 2014  (1 year 1 month) I was the sole statistician for the research lab of Dr. Nayer Khazeni. I directly collaborated with the principal investigator to conduct epidemiologic and experimental studies on topics including pandemic influenza (A) H5N1 and psychological determinants of health and health behavior. Primary responsibilities included formulating scientific questions, developing statistical analysis strategies, designing experimental and observational studies, preparing statistical graphics for scientific manuscripts, and writing manuscripts for publication in peer-reviewed journals. Independent Statistics Consultant Self-employed June 2013  –  June 2014  (1 year 1 month) I provide as-needed statistical consulting on a variety of projects. Summary I have a PhD in Biostatistics with a designated emphasis in Computational & Genomic Biology and a MPH in Epidemiology & Biostatistics from UC Berkeley. I am currently an Assistant Professor at Duke University Department of Biostatistics & Bioinformatics with a joint appointment in the Duke Clinical Research Institute (DCRI). I am a member of the Center for Predictive Medicine. 
 
I have an overall interest in the development of a "learning healthcare system" that will allow for the automatic collection of dense clinical data that can be processed and returned to clinicians and patients to allow for my effective decision making. I also have a strong interest in health policy. 
 
I enjoy working with passionate health researchers asking impactful and/or complicated questions. 
 
My current interests are in the analysis of Electronic Health Records for predicting acute adverse events in clinic settings. I am particularly interested in the analysis of real time data. I also work on developing genetic risk scores based on genome wide data. 
 
Specialties: Statistical methods for the analysis of Electronic Health Records; Genetic Association Studies; prediction & machine learning methodology; health policy; general biostatistics Summary I have a PhD in Biostatistics with a designated emphasis in Computational & Genomic Biology and a MPH in Epidemiology & Biostatistics from UC Berkeley. Specialties: Statistical methods for the analysis of Electronic Health Records; Genetic Association Studies; prediction & machine learning methodology; health policy; general biostatistics Experience Assistant Professor Duke University September 2014  – Present (1 year) Department of Biostatistics and Bioinformatics Assistant professor in the department of biostatistics & bioinformatics and joint with the Duke Clinical  
Research Institute (DCRI) and the Duke Center for Predictive Medicine.  
 
My primary research focuses on the use of Electronic Health Records for clinical risk prediction and assessment. I have been using EHR data from dialysis clinics to predict acute and real time risk of cardiac events. I also work with population EHR data available through Duke medical clinics to assess risk of diabetes and cardiovascular disease. 
 
I have a secondary interest in the use of genetic data for clinical decision making. I have developed genetic risk scores that can be automatically incorporated with individual clinical risk factors and generated during a primary care visit for personalized medicine. Statistical Consulting Goldstein Statistical Consulting 2013  – Present (2 years) I am available for statistical consulting for both long and short term projects. I have experience in many areas of statistical and biostatistical applications.  
 
Methodological Expertise: Risk prediction and assessment, machine learning, study design, paper & grant writing, statistical seminars. 
 
Subject Matter Expertise: Health related problems, electronic health records, genetic (SNP) analysis, e-health, risk reporting tools 
 
Unique Abilities: Through my position affiliation with Duke's Department of Medicine, for many health related problems I am able to partner with medical experts to add richness to the data solution. If I am not the best person for the job, I will connect you with one of my statistical colleagues who is. Summary I combine an engineer's affinity for order and efficiency with an info nerd's desire to squeeze juicy meaning from the obscuring pulp of tree-ripened data. I am comfortable with questionable metaphors. I care about people and want to make the a world better place. I have a broad interest in pulling data together, extracting meaning from it and communicating that meaning to audiences with diverse levels of expertise. I prefer creating answers with utility rather than answers of convenience and strive to make my work relevant to the real world. Summary More than seven years of experiences in advanced statistical modeling of biomedical data and knowledge of state-ofthe-art biostatistical methodologies in clinical research. My recent interest is angled towards methodologies for clinical trial designs with biomarkers. I am also interested in precision medicine: how to mine and create predictive models from large-scale healthcare data including electronic medical records and genomics and how to utilize the model in and validate the model with controlled studies such as clinical trials.
